message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the classification of celestial bodies and the concept of clearing their orbit. The phrase "clearing its orbit" refers to a planet's ability to dominate its orbit and remove or eject other celestial bodies from its path. Pluto, which used to be classified as the ninth planet in our solar system, was reclassified as a dwarf planet because it has not cleared its orbit of other debris. Option (C) refers to Neptune, the former seventh planet from the sun, which has successfully cleared its orbit. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because Venus, Earth, and Mars are not former planets and have cleared their orbits.

This question requires some basic knowledge of our solar system and the concept of clearing its orbit. According to the current definition set by the International Astronomical Union (IAU), a planet is defined as a celestial body that orbits the Sun, is spherical in shape, and has cleared its orbit of any other debris or objects. The former seventh planet, which is Uranus, has not completely cleared its orbit and therefore does not meet the criteria to be classified as a planet. Option (A) is incorrect because Venus has cleared its orbit. Option (B) is incorrect because Earth has cleared its orbit. Option (D) is incorrect because Mars has also cleared its orbit.

Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because Venus, Earth, and Mars respectively are not classified as former planets and have cleared their orbits.
